Package org.activebpel.rt.bpel.server.engine.recovery

This package contains classes for recovering or regenerating the state of a process from alarms, messages, or faults that the process received.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
IAeRecoveredItemsSet Defines the interface for a set of alarm and queue manager items generated during recoverys.
IAeRecoveryEngine Extends IAeBusinessProcessEngineInternal to define the interface for a business process engine that can recover the state of a process from a list of IAeJournalEntry instances.
IAeRecoveryProcessManager Extends IAeProcessManager to define the interface for a process manager used by an instance of AeRecoveryEngine during recovery.
IAeRecoveryQueueManager Extends IAeQueueManager to define the interface for a queue manager used by an instance of AeRecoveryEngine for recovery.
 

Class Summary
AeExecutingLocationIdsCollector Determines the location ids for activities that are currently executing by visiting the tree of BPEL implementation objects.
AeQueuedLocationIdsCollector Determines the location ids for activities that are currently queued in the queue manager or that were queued when we first retrieved journal entries for recovery.
AeRecoveredItemsSet Implements a set of recovered items representing alarm and queue manager requests.
AeRecoveryEngine Implements a business process engine that recovers the state of a process from a list of IAeJournalEntry instances.
AeRecoveryEngineFactory Implements factory object that constructs a recovery engine along with the recovery engine's managers.
AeRecoveryLockManager Implements a lock manager for recovery.
AeRecoveryProcessManager Implements a process manager for recovery.
AeRecoveryQueueManager Implements a queue manager for recovery.
 

Exception Summary
AeRecoveryConflictingRequestException Exception thrown during the recovery process to signal a conflicting request.
 

Package org.activebpel.rt.bpel.server.engine.recovery Description

This package contains classes for recovering or regenerating the state of a process from alarms, messages, or faults that the process received.
